n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:8:150" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 8, 40, 61, § 150</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">motus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:9:4:8" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 9, 4, 8</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">manus libratur artifici temperamento,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:12:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 12, 25</bibl></cit>, <cb n="ARTI" /> 54, § <cit><quote lang="la">115: artifex vultus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0969,001:5:40" default="NO"><author>Pers.</author> 5, 40</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">plaga,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Sol.</author> 35 al.</bibl></cit>—<usg type="style">Poet.</usg> of a horse, <hi rend="ital">broken</hi>, <hi rend="ital">trained</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,004:3:556" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> A. A. 3, 556</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
artificialis: <entryFree id="n3813" type="main" key="arti^fi^ci^a_lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">artĭfĭcĭālis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>artificium</etym>, <sense id="n3813.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">belonging to art</hi>, <hi rend="ital">artificial</hi>, <hi rend="ital">according to the rules of art</hi> (perh. only in Quint.): <cit><quote lang="la">probationes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:5:1:1" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 5, 1, 1</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:5:9:1" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 5, 9, 1</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:12:8:19" default="NO">12, 8, 19</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ratio,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:6:4:4" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 6, 4, 4</bibl></cit>.—Once <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">artĭfĭ-cĭālia</orth>, <itype>ium</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">things conformable to the rules of art</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:1:8:14" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 1, 8, 14</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">Adv.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">artĭ-fĭcĭālĭter</orth>, <hi rend="ital">according to art</hi> (opp. inartificialiter): <cit><quote lang="la">se gerere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:2:17:42" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 2, 17, 42</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
artificiose: <entryFree id="n3814" type="main" key="arti^fi^ci^o_se_"><orth extent="full" lang="la">artĭfĭcĭōsē</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos>, v. artificiosus <sense id="n3814.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
artificiosus: <entryFree id="n3815" type="main" key="arti^fi^ci^o_sus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">artĭfĭcĭōsus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>artificium</etym>. <sense id="n3815.0" n="I. A." level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Act.</hi>, <hi rend="ital">accomplished in art</hi>, <hi rend="ital">skilful</hi>, <hi rend="ital">artistic</hi> (perh. found only in Cic. and Auct. ad Her.): <cit><quote lang="la">rhetores elegantissimi atque artificiosissimi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,036:1:35" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Inv. 1, 35 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: quod si artificiosum est intellegere, quae sunt ex arte scripta, multo est artificiosius ipsum scribere ex arte, Auct. ad <bibl default="NO"><author>Her.</author> 4, 4, 7</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ipsius mundi natura non artificiosa solum, sed plane artifex,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:22:58" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 22, 58</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Zeno naturam ita definit, ut eam dicat ignem esse artificiosum ad gignendum progredientem viā,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 22, 58</bibl></cit>, § 57.—</sense><sense id="n3815.1" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Pass.</hi> (cf. artifex, II. B.), <hi rend="ital">on which much art has been bestowed</hi>, <hi rend="ital">made with art</hi>, <hi rend="ital">artificial</hi>, <hi rend="ital">ingenious</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">utraeque (sc. venae et arteriae) vim quandam incredibilem artificiosi operis divinique testantur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:55:138" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 55, 138</bibl></cit>: Epicurus autem nec non volt, si possit, plane et aperte loqui: nec de re obscurā, ut physici; <cit><quote lang="la">aut artificiosā, ut mathematici,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:2:5:15" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 2, 5, 15</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n3815.2" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">According to the rules of art</hi>, <hi rend="ital">artificial</hi> (esp. freq. in opp. to naturalis, <hi rend="ital">natural</hi>): <cit><quote lang="la">ea genera divinandi non naturalia, sed artificiosa dicuntur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:33:72" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 1, 33, 72</bibl></cit>; so several times Auct. ad <bibl default="NO"><author>Her.</author> 3, 16 sq.</bibl> al. —<hi rend="ital">Adv.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">artĭfĭcĭōsē</orth>, <hi rend="ital">in skilful manner</hi>, <hi rend="ital">skilfully</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">digerere aliquid,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:41:186" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 1, 41, 186</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dicere aliquid,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:3:9:32" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 3, 9, 32</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ambulare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:3:11:27" default="NO"><author>id.</author> N. D. 3, 11, 27</bibl></cit>: commutare aliquid, Auct. ad <bibl default="NO"><author>Her.</author> 3, 10, 17</bibl>.—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">multo artificiosius efficere aliquid,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:22:57" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 22, 57</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Sup.</hi>: artificiosissime facere, Auct. ad <bibl default="NO"><author>Her.</author> 4, 4, 7</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
artificium: <entryFree id="n3816" type="main" key="arti^fi^ci^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">artĭfĭcĭum</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>artifex</etym>. <sense id="n3816.0" n="I" level="1"> In gen., <hi rend="ital">the occupation of an</hi> artifex, <hi rend="ital">a profession</hi>, <hi rend="ital">trade</hi>, <hi rend="ital">an employment</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a handicraft</hi>, <hi rend="ital">an art</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Jam de artificiis et quaestibus, qui liberales habendi, qui sordidi sint, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:1:42:150" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 1, 42, 150</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne opifices quidem tueri sua artificia possent, nisi, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,048:3:2:4" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Fin. 3, 2, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">in artificio perquam tenui et levi (sc. scaenico),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:28:129" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 1, 28, 129</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sordidum ancillareque,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:5:20:58" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Tusc. 5, 20, 58</bibl></cit>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>Tac.</author> Or. 32</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ben. 6:17" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ben. 6, 17</bibl>: de hoc artificio est nobis acquisitio, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0031,005:19:25" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Act. 19, 25</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">non tu in isto artificio accusatorio callidior es quam hic in suo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,002:17:49 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Rosc. Am. 17, 49 al.</bibl></cit>—</sense><sense id="n3816.1" n="II" level="1"> Esp. </sense><sense id="n3816.2" n="A" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Skill</hi>, <hi rend="ital">knowledge</hi>, <hi rend="ital">ingenuity in any thing</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">simulacrum Dianae singulari opere artificioque perfectum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:33" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 4, 33</bibl></cit>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 4, 21</bibl>: quae certis signis artificii notata sunt, Auct. ad <bibl default="NO"><author>Her.</author> 4, 4</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n3816.3" n="B" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Theory</hi>, <hi rend="ital">system</hi> (cf. ars, I. C. 1.): <cit><quote lang="la">non esse eloquentiam ex artificio, sed artificium ex eloquentiā natum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:32:146" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 1, 32, 146</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">existimant artificium esse hoc quoddam non dissimile ceterorum, cujusmodi de ipso jure civili Crassus componi posse dicebat,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 19, 83</bibl></cit>: scientia cujusdam artificii non numquam dicitur prudentia, Auct. ad <bibl default="NO"><author>Her.</author> 3, 2</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">artificium memoriae,</quote> <trans><tr>mnemonics</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 16</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n3816.4" n="C" level="2"> <hi rend="ital">Skill serviceable in the attainment of any object</hi>, <hi rend="ital">ingenuity</hi>, <hi rend="ital">art</hi>, <hi rend="ital">dexterity;</hi> and in a bad sense, <hi rend="ital">craft</hi>, <hi rend="ital">cunning</hi>, <hi rend="ital">artifice</hi> (cf. ars, II.): <cit><quote lang="la">id ipsum, quod contra me locutus es, artificio quodam es consecutus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:17:74" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 1, 17, 74</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">opus est non solum ingenio, verum etiam artificio quodam singulari,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 4, 40 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vicinitas non assueta mendaciis, non fucosa, non fallax, non erudita artificio simulationis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,028:chapter=9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Planc. 9</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">non virtute, neque in acie vicisse Romanos, sed artificio quodam et scientiā oppugnationis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:7:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 7, 29</bibl></cit>: quorum artificiis effectum est, ut res publica in hunc statum perveniret, id. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:9:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 9, 8</bibl>, C. <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></sense></entryFree>
artio: <entryFree id="n3817" type="main" key="arti^o1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">artĭo</orth>, <itype>īvi, ītum, 4</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>1. artus</etym>, <sense id="n3817.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to fit close</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to drive in tight</hi> (only ante-class.): <cit><quote lang="la">surculum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cato</author>, R. R. 40, 3</bibl></cit>; so <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 41, 2</bibl>: linguam in palatum, Nov. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 505, 30</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n3818" type="main" key="arti^o2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">artĭo</orth>, <itype>īre</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>ars</etym>, <sense id="n3818.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to indue with art;</hi> only in the two foll. exs.: artitus: bonis instructus artibus, <hi rend="ital">skilled in arts.</hi> <cb n="ARTU" /> Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=17" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 17</bibl> Müll. (cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">centum puer artium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:4:1:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 4, 1, 15</bibl></cit>).—Hence also <hi rend="ital">endowed with cunning</hi> (cf. ars, II. <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi>), <hi rend="ital">artful</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">artiti viri,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:3:2:19" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> As. 3, 2, 19</bibl></cit> in varr. lectt.</sense></entryFree>
artisellium: <entryFree id="n3819" type="hapax" key="arti^selli^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">artĭsellĭum</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> <etym>1. artus-sella</etym>, <sense id="n3819.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an arm-chair</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Petr.</author> 75, 4</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
artius: <entryFree id="n3820" type="hapax" key="arti^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">artĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)/rtios</foreign>, <sense id="n3820.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">complete</hi>, <hi rend="ital">perfect</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">si est artius (ut ita dicam) holocleros, quid est etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cl.:4" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Claud. 4</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
arto: <entryFree id="n3821" type="main" key="arto"><orth extent="full" lang="la">arto</orth> (not <orth extent="full" lang="la">arcto</orth>), <itype>āvi, ātum, 1</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> <etym>1. artus</etym>, <sense id="n3821.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">to draw</hi> or <hi rend="ital">press close together</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to compress</hi>, <hi rend="ital">contract</hi> (not found in Cic.). </sense><sense id="n3821.1" n="I. A." level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: omnia conciliatu artari possunt, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:576" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 1, 576</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">libros,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1294,001:1:3:3" default="NO"><author>Mart.</author> 1, 3, 3</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:12:44:2" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 12, 44, 2</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">vitis contineri debet vimine, non artari,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:17:209" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 17, 23, 35, § 209</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">angustias eas artantibus insulis parvis, quae etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:3:83" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 3, 6, 13, § 83</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n3821.2" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">to contract</hi>, <hi rend="ital">straiten</hi>, <hi rend="ital">limit</hi>, <hi rend="ital">curtail</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">fortuna humana fingit artatque ut lubet, i. e. in angustias redigit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,005:2:2:54" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Capt. 2, 2, 54</bibl></cit> Lind.; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:45:56" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 45, 56</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">tempus,</quote> <trans><tr>to limit</tr>, <tr>circumscribe</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:42:1:2" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 42, 1, 2</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:38:9:1" default="NO">38, 9, 1</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">se,</quote> <trans><tr>to limit one's self</tr>, <tr>to retrench</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:1:11:2 al" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 1, 11, 2 al.</bibl></cit> —</sense><sense id="n3821.3" n="II" level="1"> In gen., <hi rend="ital">to finish</hi>, <hi rend="ital">conclude</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Petr.</author> 85, 4</bibl>.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">artātus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>P. a.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">contracted into a small compass;</hi> hence, <hi rend="ital">narrow</hi>, <hi rend="ital">close;</hi> and of time, <hi rend="ital">short</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">pontus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:5:234" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 5, 234</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tempus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1044,001:1:16" default="NO"><author>Vell.</author> 1, 16</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
artocopus: <entryFree id="n3822" type="greek" key="arto^co^pus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">artŏcŏpus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)rtoko/pos</foreign>, <sense id="n3822.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a baker</hi>, Firm. Math. 8, 20.</sense></entryFree>
artocreas: <entryFree id="n3823" type="greek" key="arto_^cre^as"><orth extent="full" lang="la">artō^crĕas</orth>, <itype>ătis</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)rto/kreas</foreign>, <sense id="n3823.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a meat pie</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0969,001:6:50" default="NO"><author>Pers.</author> 6, 50</bibl>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 4937</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
artolaganus: <entryFree id="n3824" type="main" key="arto^la^ga^nus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">artŏlăgănus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)rtola/ganon</foreign>, <sense id="n3824.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a kind of bread</hi> or <hi rend="ital">cake</hi> (<hi rend="ital">made of meal</hi>, <hi rend="ital">wine</hi>, <hi rend="ital">milk</hi>, <hi rend="ital">oil</hi>, <hi rend="ital">lard</hi>, <hi rend="ital">and pepper</hi>, Athen. 3, 28); <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,056:9:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Fam. 9, 20</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
artopta: <entryFree id="n3825" type="greek" key="artopta"><orth extent="full" lang="la">artopta</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)rto/pths</foreign>. * <sense id="n3825.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A baker</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1276,001:5:72" default="NO"><author>Juv.</author> 5, 72</bibl> Ruperti.—</sense><sense id="n3825.1" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A vessel to bake in</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a bread-pan</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,003:2:9:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Aul. 2, 9, 4</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:18:107" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 18, 11, 28, § 107</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
artopticius: <entryFree id="n3826" type="main" key="artopti_ci^us"><orth extent="full" lang="la">artoptīcĭus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>artopta, II.</etym>, <sense id="n3826.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">baked in an</hi> artopta: <cit><quote lang="la">panis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:18:105" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 18, 11, 27, § 105</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
artotrogus: <entryFree id="n3827" type="greek" key="Arto_^tro_gus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Artō^trōgus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym><foreign lang="greek">a)/rtos-trw/gw</foreign>, bread-gnawer</etym>, <sense id="n3827.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the name of a parasite in</hi> Plaut. Mil.</sense></entryFree>
artotyritae: <entryFree id="n3828" type="greek" key="Arto^ty_ri_tae"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Artŏtȳrītae</orth>, <itype>ārum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym><foreign lang="greek">a)/rtos-turo/s</foreign></etym>, <sense id="n3828.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">heretics who made offerings of bread and cheese</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2468,001:de Haeres. 25" default="NO"><author>Aug.</author> de Haeres. 25</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
artro: <entryFree id="n3829" type="main" key="artro"><orth extent="full" lang="la">artro</orth>, <itype>āre</itype>, v. aratro.</entryFree>
artua: <entryFree id="n3830" type="main" key="artu^a"><orth extent="full" lang="la">artŭa</orth>, v. artus <sense id="n3830.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">init.</hi></sense></entryFree>
artuatim: <entryFree id="n3831" type="hapax" key="artu^a_tim"><orth extent="full" lang="la">artŭātim</orth>, <pos>adv.</pos> <etym>2. artus</etym>, <sense id="n3831.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">limb by limb</hi>, Firm. Math. 7, 1.</sense></entryFree>
artuatus: <entryFree id="n3832" type="main" key="artu^a_tus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">artŭātus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <mood>Part.</mood> [qs. <mood>Part.</mood> of artuo, āre], <sense id="n3832.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">torn in pieces</hi>, Firm. Math. 6, 31.</sense></entryFree>
artus: <entryFree id="n3833" type="main" key="artus1" n="1"><orth extent="full" lang="la">artus</orth> (not <orth extent="full" lang="la">arctus</orth>), <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>v. arma</etym>, prop. <sense id="n3833.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fitted;</hi> hence, </sense><sense id="n3833.1" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">close</hi>, <hi rend="ital">strait</hi>, <hi rend="ital">narrow</hi>, <hi rend="ital">confined</hi>, <hi rend="ital">short</hi>, <hi rend="ital">brief</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">exierunt regionibus artis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:120" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 6, 120</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">claustra,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:70" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 1, 70</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:808" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 3, 808</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec tamen haec ita sunt arta et astricta, ut ea laxare nequeamus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,040:65:220" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Or. 65, 220</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">artioribus apud populum Romanum laqueis tenebitur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:1:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Verr. 2, 1, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nullum vinculum ad astringendam fidem jure jurando majores artius esse voluerunt,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:31:111" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Off. 3, 31, 111</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">compages,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:293" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 293</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">nexus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:6:242" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 6, 242</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">arto stipata theatro,</quote> <trans><tr>pressed together in a contracted theatre</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 2, 1, 60</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">toga,</quote> <trans><tr>a narrow toga without folds</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 18, 30</bibl></cit> (cf. exigua toga, <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 19, 13</bibl>): <cit><quote lang="la">nimis arta convivia,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>with too many guests</tr>, <tr>who are therefore compelled to sit close together</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 5, 29</bibl></cit> et saep.—Hence, <hi rend="ital">subst.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">artum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, <hi rend="ital">a narrow place</hi> or <hi rend="ital">passage</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ventus cum confercit, franguntur in arto montes nimborum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:158" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 6, 158</bibl></cit> Lachm.: <cit><quote lang="la">multiplicatis in arto ordinibus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:50" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 50</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:34:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 34, 15</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec desilies imitator in artum,</quote> <trans><tr>nor</tr>, <tr>by imitating</tr>, <tr>leap into a close place</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,006:134" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> A. P. 134</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n3833.2" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">strict</hi>, <hi rend="ital">severe</hi>, <hi rend="ital">scanty</hi>, <hi rend="ital">brief</hi>, <hi rend="ital">small</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">sponte suā cecidit sub leges artaque jura,</quote> <trans><tr>subjected himself to the severity of the laws</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:1147" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 5, 1147</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Additae leges artae et ideo superbae quasque etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:16:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 16, 4, 5, § 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vincula amoris artissima,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,057:6:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Att. 6, 2</bibl></cit>: artior somnus, <hi rend="ital">a sounder</hi> or <hi rend="ital">deeper sleep</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:6:10" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Rep. 6, 10</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">arti commeatus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 34</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:4:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 4, 26</bibl>; cf.: <cit><quote lang="la">in arto commeatus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 3, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">artissimae tenebrae,</quote> <trans><tr>very thick darkness</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=nero:46" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Ner. 46</bibl></cit> (for which, in class. Lat., densus, v. Bremi ad h. l., and cf. densus) al.—So, colligere in artum, <hi rend="ital">to compress</hi>, <hi rend="ital">abridge</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">quae (volumina) a me collecta in artum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:8:44" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 8, 16, 17, § 44</bibl></cit>.—Of hope, <hi rend="ital">small</hi>, <hi rend="ital">scanty</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">spes artior aquae manantis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:1:5:2" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 1, 5, 2</bibl></cit>: ne spem sibi ponat in arto, <hi rend="ital">diminish hope</hi>, <hi rend="ital">expectation</hi>, <pb n="169" /> <cb n="ARUN" /> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:9:683" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 9, 683</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quia plus quam unum ex patriciis creari non licebat, artior petitio quattuor petentibus erat,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>was harder</tr>, <tr>had less ground of hope</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:39:32" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 39, 32</bibl></cit>; and of circumstances in life, etc., <hi rend="ital">straitened</hi>, <hi rend="ital">distressing</hi>, <hi rend="ital">wretched</hi>, <hi rend="ital">needy</hi>, <hi rend="ital">indigent</hi> (so in and after the Aug. per. for the class. angustus): <cit><quote lang="la">rebus in artis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,009:3:2:25" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> P. 3, 2, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">artas res nuntiaret,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:3:69" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 3, 69</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">tam artis afflictisque rebus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:2:6:31" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 2, 6, 31</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:7:310" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 7, 310</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">fortuna artior expensis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,002:5:3:117" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> S. 5, 3, 117</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne in arto res esset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:26:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 26, 17</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Adv.</hi>: <orth extent="full" lang="la">artē</orth> (not <orth extent="full" lang="la">arcte</orth>), <hi rend="ital">closely</hi>, <hi rend="ital">close</hi>, <hi rend="ital">fast</hi>, <hi rend="ital">firmly.</hi> </sense><sense id="n3833.3" n="I" level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">arte (manus) conliga,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,009:5:2:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Ep. 5, 2, 29</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">boves arte ad stipites religare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:6:2:5" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 6, 2, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">arte continere aliquid,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:7:23" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 7, 23</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">aciem arte statuere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 52:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 52, 6</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">arte accubare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,018:4:2:39" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Stich. 4, 2, 39</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Comp.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">calorem artius continere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:9:25" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 9, 25</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">artius astringi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,003:15:5" default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Epod. 15, 5</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">signa artius conlocare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:C. 59:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> C. 59, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">artius ire,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0860,001:4:13:34" default="NO"><author>Curt.</author> 4, 13, 34</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">artius pressiusque conflictari,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:10:6" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 10, 6</bibl></cit>.—<hi rend="ital">Sup.</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">milites quam artissime ire jubet,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 68:4" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 68, 4</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">artissime plantas serere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:12:16" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 12, 3, 7, § 16</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n3833.4" n="II" level="1"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">arte contenteque aliquem habere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,002:1:1:63" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> As. 1, 1, 63</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,011:prol. 64" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Merc. prol. 64</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">arte et graviter dormire,</quote> <trans><tr>soundly</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:28:59" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 1, 28, 59</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">arte appellare aliquem,</quote> <trans><tr>briefly</tr>, <tr>by shortening his name</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,009:4:12:10" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> P. 4, 12, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">artius adstringere rationem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,054:14:32" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Fat. 14, 32</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">abstinentiam artissime constringere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1038,001:2:2:8" default="NO"><author>Val. Max.</author> 2, 2, 8</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n3833.5" n="III" level="1"> <usg type="style">Transf.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">arte diligere aliquem,</quote> <trans><tr>strongly</tr>, <tr>deeply</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:6:8" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 6, 8</bibl></cit>; so also <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:ib. 2:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 13</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>

<entryFree id="n3834" type="main" key="artus2" n="2"><orth extent="full" lang="la">artus</orth>, <itype>ūs</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> <etym>id.</etym>, mostly <number>plur.</number> (artua, <gen>n.</gen>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:5:2:102" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Men. 5, 2, 102</bibl>; quoted in <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 191, 12</bibl>.—Hence, <case>dat.</case> acc. to Vel. Long. p. 2229 P. and <bibl default="NO"><author>Ter.</author> Scaur. p. 2260</bibl> P. artibus; yet the ancient grammarians give their decision in favor of artubus, which form is also supported by the best MSS.; cf. arcus.—The singular is found only in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:6:754" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 6, 754</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:4:310" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 4, 310</bibl>, and <bibl default="NO"><author>Prisc.</author> p. 1219</bibl> P.). <sense id="n3834.0" n="I. A." level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">a joint</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">molles commissurae et artus (digitorum),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:2:60:150" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 2, 60, 150</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">suffraginum artus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:11:248" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 11, 45, 101, § 248</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">elapsi in pravum artus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:4:81" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 4, 81</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">dolor artuum,</quote> <trans><tr>gout</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,039:60:217" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Brut. 60, 217</bibl></cit>.—Sometimes connected with membra, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,010:5:2:102" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Men. 5, 2, 102</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">copia materiaï Cogitur interdum flecti per membra, per artus,</quote> <trans><tr>in every joint and limb</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:282" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 2, 282</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:703 al" default="NO" valid="yes">3, 703 al.</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cal.:28" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Calig. 28</bibl>; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">Baumg.-Crus., Clavis ad Suet.: cernere laceros artus, truncata membra,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,002:52:5" default="NO"><author>Plin.</author> Pan. 52, 5</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n3834.1" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">the muscular strength in the joints;</hi> hence, in gen., <hi rend="ital">strength</hi>, <hi rend="ital">power</hi>: <foreign lang="greek">*)epixarmei=on</foreign> illud teneto; <cit><quote lang="la">nervos atque artus esse sapientiae, non temere credere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0478,001:Petit. Cons. 10" default="NO"><author>Q. Cic.</author> Petit. Cons. 10</bibl></cit>.—More freq., </sense><sense id="n3834.2" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">The limbs</hi> in gen. (very freq., esp. in the poets; in Lucr. about sixty times): cum tremulis anus attulit artubus lumen, Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:20:40" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Div. 1, 20, 40</bibl> (Ann. v. 36 Vahl.); so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 3, 7</bibl>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:488" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 3, 488</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:6:1189" default="NO" valid="yes">6, 1189</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">artubus omnibus contremiscam,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:1:26:121" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> de Or. 1, 26, 121</bibl></cit>: dum nati (sc. Absyrti) dissupatos artus captaret parens, vet. <usg type="style">poet.</usg> ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:3:26:67" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 3, 26, 67</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">copia concita per artus Omnīs,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:267" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 2, 267</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">moribundi artus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:129 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 3, 129 al.</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">rogumque parari Vidit et arsuros supremis ignibus artus, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:2:620 al" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 2, 620 al.</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">salsusque per artus Sudor iit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:2:173" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 2, 173</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">1, 173 al.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">veste strictā et singulos artus exprimente,</quote> <trans><tr>and showing each limb</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,002:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> G. 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">artus in frusta concident,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,003:1:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Lev. 1, 6</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">8, 20</bibl>; <cit><quote lang="la">ib. Job, 16, 8.—Of plants: stat per se vitis sine ullo pedamento, artus suos in se colligens,</quote> <trans><tr>its tendrils</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:14:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 14, 1, 3, § 13</bibl></cit>, where Jahn reads <hi rend="ital">arcus.</hi></sense></entryFree>
arula: <entryFree id="n3835" type="main" key="a_ru^la"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ārŭla</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <lbl>dim.</lbl> <etym>ara</etym>. <sense id="n3835.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A small altar</hi>: ante hosce deos erant arulae, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,005:4:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Verr. 2, 4, 3</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,049:36:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Jer. 36, 22</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">36, 23</bibl> <hi rend="ital">bis;</hi> Jus Papir. in <bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> S. 3, 11</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Arn.</author> 3, p. 114</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> 1630</bibl>.—†† </sense><sense id="n3835.1" n="II" level="1"> Perh. <hi rend="ital">the base</hi> of an altar (eccl. Lat.): <cit><quote lang="la">quos (anulos) pones subter arulam altaris,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,002:27:5" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Exod. 27, 5</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO">38, 4</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n3835.2" n="III" level="1"> Among the Campanians, <hi rend="ital">the turf laid altar-like round an elm-tree</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:17:77" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 17, 11, 15, § 77</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
arum: <entryFree id="n3836" type="main" key="a^rum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ărum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, v. aros.</entryFree>
aruncus: <entryFree id="n3837" type="greek" key="a_runcus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">āruncus</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">h)/ruggos</foreign> (Dor. <foreign lang="greek">a)/ruggos</foreign>), <sense id="n3837.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">the beard of the goat</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:8:203" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 8, 50, 76, § 203</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
arundifer: <entryFree id="n3838" type="hapax" key="a^rundi^fer"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ărundĭfer, ărundĭnācĕus</orth>, <orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">ărundo</orth> and its derivv., v. harundifer, etc.</entryFree>
arundulatio: <entryFree id="n3839" type="main" key="a^rundu^la_tio"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ărundŭlātio</orth>, v. harundinatio.</entryFree>
aruns: <entryFree id="n3840" type="main" key="Aruns"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Aruns</orth>, <itype>untis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, <sense id="n3840.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">an Etruscan name of</hi> <cb n="ARVU" /> <hi rend="ital">the younger son</hi>, while the elder was called Lar or Lars [in pure Etruscan, Arnth.; Gr. <foreign lang="greek">*)/arrwn</foreign> or <foreign lang="greek">*)arrou=ns</foreign>]. </sense><sense id="n3840.1" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A brother of Lucumo</hi> (Tarquinius Priscus), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 34</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n3840.2" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A younger son of Tarquin the Proud</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:56" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 56</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:6" default="NO" valid="yes">2, 6</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n3840.3" n="III" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">A son of Porsenna</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:2:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 2, 14</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n3840.4" n="IV" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">An Etruscan seer</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:1:585" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 1, 585</bibl>; v. Müll. Etrusk. 1, pp. 405 and 409.</sense></entryFree>
arupium: <entryFree id="n3841" type="main" key="A^ru_pi^um"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Ărūpĭum</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)arou/peinon</foreign>, Strabo, <sense id="n3841.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a town in Illyria</hi>, now <hi rend="ital">Auersperg</hi>, Itin. Anton.—Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Ărūpīnus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <hi rend="ital">of</hi> or <hi rend="ital">pertaining to Arupium</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Arupinis natus in arvis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0660,001:4:1:110" default="NO"><author>Tib.</author> 4, 1, 110</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
arura: <entryFree id="n3842" type="greek" key="a^ru_ra"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ărūra</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)/roura</foreign>, <sense id="n3842.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a field</hi>, <hi rend="ital">cornfield</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Marc. Emp.</author> 8</bibl>; Vel. Long. p. 2246 P.</sense></entryFree>
aruspex: <entryFree id="n3843" type="main" key="a^ruspex"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ăruspex</orth> and derivv., v. haruspex, etc.</entryFree>
arvalis: <entryFree id="n3844" type="main" key="arva_lis"><orth extent="full" lang="la">arvālis</orth>, <itype>e</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>arvum</etym>, <sense id="n3844.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">pertaining to a cultivated field;</hi> hence, Fratres Arvales, <hi rend="ital">a college of twelve priests</hi>, <hi rend="ital">who yearly made offerings to the field-Lares for the increase of the fruits of the field</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Fratres Arvales dicti sunt, qui sacra publica faciunt propterea, ut fruges ferant arva,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 5:section=85" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 5, § 85</bibl></cit> Müll.; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 560, 24 sq.</bibl>; Müll. Etrusk. 2, pp. 91 and 105. Extant inscriptions show that this college of priests continued in existence until the fourth century; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Inscr. Orell.</author> I. 388 sq.</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">5054</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">807</bibl>; 840; 858; 903; 947; 961 al.</sense></entryFree>
arveho: <entryFree id="n3845" type="main" key="arve^ho"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ar-vĕho</orth>, <itype>exi, ectum, 3</itype>, <pos>v. a.</pos> (an old form for adveho, v. ad <sense id="n3845.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">init.</hi>), <hi rend="ital">to bring</hi>, <hi rend="ital">to procure</hi> (only twice in Cato): <cit><quote lang="la">arvehant ligna,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Cato</author>, R. R. 138</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">trapetum ubi arvectum erit,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 135, 7</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
arverni: <entryFree id="n3846" type="main" key="Arverni"><orth extent="full" lang="la">Arverni</orth>, <itype>ōrum</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*)arbernoi/</foreign>, Plut.; <foreign lang="greek">*)arouernoi/</foreign>, Strabo, <sense id="n3846.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a people of Gaul</hi>, <hi rend="ital">in the present</hi> Auvergne, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0448,001:1:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Caes.</author> B. G. 1, 31</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">1, 45</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">7, 7</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:1:427" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 1, 427</bibl>; cf. Mann. Gall. p. 130.— Hence, <orth extent="full" lang="la">Arvernus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos>, <hi rend="ital">Arvernian</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Arvernum genus (vini),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:14:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 14, 1, 3, § 18</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
arviga: <entryFree id="n3847" type="main" key="arviga"><orth extent="full" lang="la">arviga</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">harv-</orth>), v. arvix.</entryFree>
arvina: <entryFree id="n3848" type="main" key="arvi_na"><orth extent="full" lang="la">arvīna</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <sense id="n3848.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Grease</hi>, <hi rend="ital">fat</hi>, <hi rend="ital">suet</hi>, <hi rend="ital">lard.</hi> </sense><sense id="n3848.1" n="A" level="2"> In gen.: pinguis, * <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:7:627" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 7, 627</bibl> (secundum Suetonium arvina est durum pingue, quod est inter cutem et viscus, Serv.).—</sense><sense id="n3848.2" n="B" level="2"> Esp. </sense><sense id="n3848.3" n="a" level="4"> Of the victim in a sacrifice (eccl. Lat.), <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,002:29:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Exod. 29, 22</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,003:3:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> Lev. 3, 15</bibl>; so the <lbl>dim.</lbl> arvinula, * <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> ib. 8, 16</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n3848.4" n="b" level="4"> Of a person: <cit><quote lang="la">de latere ejus arvina dependet,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Vulg.</author> Job, 15, 27</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n3848.5" n="II" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">Greasiness</hi>, <hi rend="ital">fatness</hi>, in gen., <bibl default="NO"><author>Prud.</author> Cath. 7, 9</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Sid.</author> Ep. 8, 14</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n3848.6" n="III" level="1"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">Arvīna</orth>, <hi rend="ital">a surname of the dictator</hi> A. Cornelius Cossus, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:8:38" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 8, 38</bibl>.</sense></entryFree>
arvinula: <entryFree id="n3849" type="main" key="arvi_nu^la"><orth extent="full" lang="la">arvīnŭla</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, v. arvina, I. B. a.</entryFree>
arvix: <entryFree id="n3850" type="greek" key="arvix"><orth extent="full" lang="la">arvix</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">harvix</orth>, <itype>ĭgis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">*a*r*i*c</foreign>, with digamma <foreign lang="greek">*a*r*v*i*c</foreign>, also as <sense id="n3850.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">fem.</hi> <orth extent="full" lang="la">arvi-ga</orth> (<orth type="alt" extent="full" lang="la">harv-</orth>), <itype>ae</itype>, <hi rend="ital">a ram for offering</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Aries qui etiam dicebatur Ares, veteres nostri Arviga, hinc Arvigas,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 5:section=98" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 5, § 98</bibl></cit> Lindem.: Harviga dicebatur hostia, cujus adhaerentia inspiciebantur exta, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=100" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 100</bibl> Mūll. (in Don. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:4:4:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. 4, 4, 28</bibl>, haruga; in Vel. Long. p. 2233 P. ariuga).</sense></entryFree>
arvum: <entryFree id="n3851" type="main" key="arvum"><orth extent="full" lang="la">arvum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen>, v. arvus, II. B.</entryFree>
arvus: <entryFree id="n3852" type="main" key="arvus"><orth extent="full" lang="la">arvus</orth>, <itype>a, um</itype>, <pos>adj.</pos> <etym>for aruus from aro</etym>. <sense id="n3852.0" n="I" level="1"> <hi rend="ital">That has been ploughed</hi>, <hi rend="ital">but not yet sown</hi>, <hi rend="ital">ploughed</hi>, <hi rend="ital">arable</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">ager, arvus et arationes ab arando,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 5:section=39" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 5, § 39</bibl></cit> Müll.: <cit><quote lang="la">arvum, quod aratum nec dum satum est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 1:29" default="NO"><author>id.</author> R. R. 1, 29</bibl></cit>; Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=25" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 25</bibl> Müll.: <cit><quote lang="la">aut arvus est ager aut consitus aut pascuus aut florens,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Isid.</author> Orig. 15, 13</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Non arvus hic, sed pascuus est ager,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,020:1:2:47" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Truc. 1, 2, 47</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">agri arvi et arbusti et pascui lati atque uberes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,043:5:2:3" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Rep. 5, 2, 3</bibl></cit>.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n3852.1" n="II" level="1"> <pos>Subst.</pos> </sense><sense id="n3852.2" n="A" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">arva</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> (sc. terra), <hi rend="ital">an arable field</hi>, <hi rend="ital">cornfield;</hi> only twice, ante - class., Naev. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 192, 30</bibl>; Pac. ib.—</sense><sense id="n3852.3" n="B" level="2"> <orth extent="full" lang="la">arvum</orth>, <itype>i</itype>, <gen>n.</gen> (sc. solum), <hi rend="ital">an arable field</hi>, <hi rend="ital">cultivated land</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a field</hi>, <hi rend="ital">ploughed land</hi>, <hi rend="ital">glebe</hi> (cf. Doed. Syn. III. p. 8; <cit><quote lang="la">class.): nec scibat ferro molirier arva,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:934" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 5, 934</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:1:314" default="NO" valid="yes">1, 314</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">sol lumine conserit arva,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:211" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 2, 211</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:1162" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 2, 1162</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:1:598" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 1, 598</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">11, 33</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:2:263" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 2, 263</bibl> et saep.: <cit><quote lang="la">ex arvo aeque magno,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 1:7:2" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 1, 7, 2</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">prata et arva et pecudum greges diliguntur isto modo, quod fructus ex eis capiuntur,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,050:1:44:122" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> N. D. 1, 44, 122</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">arva non afferent cibum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,043:3:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Hab. 3, 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Numidae pabulo pecoris magis quam arvo student,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0631,001:J. 90:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Sall.</author> J. 90, 1</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ne perconteris, fundus meus, optime Quincti, Arvo pascat erum,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Hor.</author> Ep. 1, 16, 2</bibl></cit> (i. e. frugibus: <cit><quote lang="la">arvum autem ab arando dictum est, Crucq.): arva per annos mutant, et superest ager,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,002:26" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> G. 26</bibl></cit>; <cb n="ARX" /> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=nero:31" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Ner. 31</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=dom.:7" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Dom. 7</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n3852.4" n="2" level="3"> <usg type="style">Meton.</usg> </sense><sense id="n3852.5" n="a" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">A region</hi>, <hi rend="ital">country</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Aspicis en praesens, quali jaceamus in arvo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,009:4:7:3" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> P. 4, 7, 3</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n3852.6" n="b" level="4"> <usg type="style">Poet.</usg>, in gen., <hi rend="ital">fields</hi>, <hi rend="ital">plains</hi>, <hi rend="ital">regions</hi>: arva putria, Liv. And. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=181" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 181</bibl> Müll.: <cit><quote lang="la">genus humanum multo fuit in arvis durius,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:925" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 5, 925</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:2:1154" default="NO" valid="yes">2, 1154</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">nec pisces (queunt) vivere in arvis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:3:785" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 3, 785</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Circaea arva,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:14:348" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 14, 348</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Peneïa,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:12:209" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 12, 209</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:15:52" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 15, 52</bibl>; 15, 276; 11, 62; 11, 196; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:5:703" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 5, 703</bibl> et saep.: <cit><quote lang="la">pomosa,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:5:7:81" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 5, 7, 81</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quā tumidus rigat arva Nilus,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:3:3:48" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 3, 3, 48</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,003:16:54" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Epod. 16, 54</bibl>; so, <cit><quote lang="la">arva deserti,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,049:23:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> Jer. 23, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">arva pacis,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>ib.</author> ib. 25, 37</bibl></cit>.—Hence also, </sense><sense id="n3852.7" n="(a)" level="5"> For pascuum, <hi rend="ital">pasture-ground</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">Arvaque mugitu sancite bovaria longo: Nobile erit Romae pascua vestra forum,</quote> <trans>i. e. <tr>the Forum Boarium at Rome</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1224,001:5:9:19" default="NO"><author>Prop.</author> 5, 9, 19</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n3852.8" n="(b)" level="5"> Arva Neptunia, for <hi rend="ital">the sea</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:8:695" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 8, 695</bibl> (cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 6, 724</bibl>: campi liquentes). —</sense><sense id="n3852.9" n="(g)" level="5"> <hi rend="ital">Land</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a shore</hi>, <hi rend="ital">coast</hi>: <cit><quote lang="la">jamque arva tenebant (angues),</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:2:209" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 2, 209</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
arx: <entryFree id="n3853" type="main" key="arx"><orth extent="full" lang="la">arx</orth>, <itype>arcis</itype>, <gen>f.</gen> <etym>arx ab arcendo, quod is locus munitissimus rubis, a quo facillime possit hostis prohiberi, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 5:section=151" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 5, § 151</bibl> Müll; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>Serv.</author> ad Verg. A. 1, 20</bibl>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Isid.</author> Orig. 15, 2, 32</bibl>; Doed. Syn. IV. p. 428; v. arceo</etym>, <sense id="n3853.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a stronghold</hi>, <hi rend="ital">castle</hi>, <hi rend="ital">citadel</hi>, <hi rend="ital">fortress</hi>, <foreign lang="greek">a)kro/polis</foreign>; in Rome, <hi rend="ital">the Capitolium.</hi> </sense><sense id="n3853.1" n="I. A." level="1"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: arce et urbe orba sum, Enn. ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,049:3:19:44" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Tusc. 3, 19, 44</bibl> (Trag. v. 114 Müll.): optumates, Corinthum quae arcem altam habetis, id. ap. ejusd. Fam. 7, 6: edicite per urbem ut omnes qui arcem astuque accolunt, cives, etc.; Att. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 357, 14</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Illa autem in arcem [hinc] abiit,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,004:4:8:59" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plaut.</author> Bacch. 4, 8, 59</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0119,016:4:6:2" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Ps. 4, 6, 2</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">In arcem transcurso opus est,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,005:3:4:17" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Hec. 3, 4, 17</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Condere coeperunt urbīs arcemque locare,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:5:1107" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Lucr.</author> 5, 1107</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">arcis servator, candidus anser,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0550,001:4:683" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 4, 683</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">munire arcem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:chapter=34" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Pis. 34 <hi rend="ital">fin.</hi></bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">cum Tarento amisso arcem tamen Livius retinuisset,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,037:2:67:273" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> de Or. 2, 67, 273</bibl></cit>: arx intra moenia in immanem altitudinem edita; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:45:28" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 45, 28</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">arx Sion,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,012:5:7" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vulg.</author> 2 Reg. 5, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">arx Jerusalem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:tlg,0527,023:13:49" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>ib.</author> 1 Macc. 13, 49</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Romana,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:12" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 12</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Capitolina,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:6:20" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 6, 20</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 3, 18</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Sabinus arcem Capitolii insedit mixto milite,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,004:3:69" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> H. 3, 69</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=cl.:44" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Claud. 44</bibl> et saep. As the place on which auguries were received (cf. auguraculum): <cit><quote lang="la">ut cum in arce augurium augures acturi essent,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,055:3:16:66" default="NO"><author>Cic.</author> Off. 3, 16, 66</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:1:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 1, 18</bibl> and 24.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n3853.2" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">defence</hi>, <hi rend="ital">prolection</hi>, <hi rend="ital">refuge</hi>, <hi rend="ital">bulwark</hi>, etc.: <cit><quote lang="la">Castoris templum fuit te consule arx civium perditorum, receptaculum veterum Catilinae militum, castellum forensis latrocinii,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,027:5:11" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Pis. 5, 11</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">haec urbs, lux orbis terrarum atque arx omnium gentium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,013:4:6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Cat. 4, 6</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,011:1:6:18" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Agr. 1, 6, 18</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Africa arx omnium provinciarum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,033:7:22" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Lig. 7, 22</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Stoicorum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,053:1:6:10" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Div. 1, 6, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">arx finitimorum, Campani,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:7:29" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 7, 29</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:37:18" default="NO" valid="yes">37, 18</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">tribunicium auxilium et provocationem, duas arces libertatis tuendae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:3:45" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 3, 45</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">arx ad aliquid faciendum,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:28:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 28, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">eam urbem pro arce habiturus Philippus adversus Graeciae civitates,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:33:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 33, 14</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1242,001:3:6:5" default="NO"><author>Flor.</author> 3, 6, 5</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">quasi arx aeternae dominationis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1351,005:14:31" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Tac.</author> A. 14, 31</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n3853.3" n="C" level="2"> As the abode of tyrants, a <usg type="style">poet.</usg> designation of <hi rend="ital">tyranny</hi> (cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0803,001:ad Cic. Div. in Caecil. 5" default="NO"><author>Ascon.</author> ad Cic. Div. in Caecil. 5</bibl>), <bibl default="NO"><author>Claud.</author> IV. Cons. Hon. 293</bibl> Heins.: <cit><quote lang="la">cupidi arcium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Thyest. 342" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Thyest. 342</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Contr. 4:27" default="NO"><author>id.</author> Contr. 4, 27</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">non dum attigit arcem, Juris et humani culmen,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:7:593" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Luc.</author> 7, 593</bibl></cit> Corte; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0917,001:8:490" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 8, 490</bibl>, and 4, 800; <bibl default="NO"><author>Tert.</author> Apol. 4</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n3853.4" n="D" level="2"> Prov.: <cit><quote lang="la">arcem facere e cloacā,</quote> <trans><tr>to make a mountain of a mole-hill</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,028:chapter=40" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Planc. 40</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n3853.5" n="II" level="1"> Since castles were generally on a height, meton., <hi rend="ital">a height</hi>, <hi rend="ital">summit</hi>, <hi rend="ital">pinnacle</hi>, <hi rend="ital">top</hi>, <hi rend="ital">peak</hi> (usu. <usg type="style">poet.</usg> and in Aug. and postAug. prose), lit. and trop. </sense><sense id="n3853.6" n="A" level="2"> <usg type="style">Lit.</usg>: <cit><quote lang="la">summā locum sibi legit in arce,</quote> <trans><tr>upon the extreme height</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:1:27" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 1, 27</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:12:43" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 12, 43</bibl>. —So, </sense><sense id="n3853.7" n="2" level="3"> In partic. </sense><sense id="n3853.8" n="a" level="4"> Of mountains: <cit><quote lang="la">Parnasi constitit arce,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:1:467" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 1, 467</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">arce loci summā,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:11:393" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 11, 393</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Rhipaeae arces,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,002:1:240" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> G. 1, 240</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">flērunt Rhodopeïae arces,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 4, 461</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">septemque unā sibi muro circumdedit arces,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 535</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">primus inexpertas adiit Tirynthius arces, i. e. Alpes,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:3:496" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 3, 496</bibl></cit>; cf. Drak. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:15:305" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 15, 305</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1035,001:3:565" default="NO"><author>Val. Fl.</author> 3, 565</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">impositum arce sublimi oppidum cernimus,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Petr.</author> 116</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> 123, 205</bibl>, and 209.—</sense><sense id="n3853.9" n="b" level="4"> Of houses built on an eminence, <bibl default="NO"><author>Petr.</author> 121, 107</bibl>, and 293.—</sense><sense id="n3853.10" n="c" level="4"> Of the citadel of heaven: <cit><quote lang="la">quae pater ut summā vidit Saturnius arce,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,006:1:163" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> M. 1, 163</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">summam petit arduus arcem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,010:2:306" default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 2, 306</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sideream mundi qui temperat arcem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,001:3:10:21" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> Am. 3, 10, 21</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n3853.11" n="d" level="4"> Of the heavens themselves: aetheriae<pb n="170" /> <cb n="AS" />  arces, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,008:5:3:19" default="NO"><author>Ov.</author> Tr. 5, 3, 19</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">arces igneae,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:3:3:10" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 3, 3, 10</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">caeli quibus adnuis arcem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0690,003:1:250" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Verg.</author> A. 1, 250</bibl></cit>; cf. <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> ib. 1, 259</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n3853.12" n="e" level="4"> Of temples erected on an eminence: <cit><quote lang="la">dexterā sacras jaculatus arces,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,001:1:2:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> C. 1, 2, 3</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n3853.13" n="f" level="4"> Of the head: <cit><quote lang="la">arx corporis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Oedip. 185" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Oedip. 185</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Claud.</author> IV. Cons. Hon. 235</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n3853.14" n="B" level="2"> <usg type="style">Trop.</usg>, <hi rend="ital">height</hi>, <hi rend="ital">head</hi>, <hi rend="ital">summit</hi>, etc. (rare): <cit><quote lang="la">celsā mentis ab arce,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1020,002:2:2:131" default="NO"><author>Stat.</author> S. 2, 2, 131</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">summae laudum arces,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1345,001:13:771" default="NO"><author>Sil.</author> 13, 771</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Sid.</author> Carm. 2, 173</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">ubi Hannibal sit, ibi caput atque arcem totius belli esse,</quote> <trans><tr>head and front</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0914,001:28:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Liv.</author> 28, 42</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">arx eloquentiae,</quote> <bibl default="NO"><author>Tac.</author> Or. 10</bibl></cit>.</sense></entryFree>
arytaena: <entryFree id="n3854" type="greek" key="a^ry^taena"><orth extent="full" lang="la">ărytaena</orth> or <orth extent="full" lang="la">ărŭtaena</orth>, also contr. <orth extent="full" lang="la">artaena</orth>, <itype>ae</itype>, <gen>f.</gen>, = <foreign lang="greek">a)rutainh</foreign>, <sense id="n3854.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">a vessel for taking up liquids</hi>: arytaenam sive artaenam vas ab hauriendo sic appellabant, Paul. ex <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1236,001:page=21" default="NO"><author>Fest.</author> p. 21</bibl> Müll.: artaenaeque et aquales, Lucil. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> p. 95</bibl> (1, 35 Müll.).</sense></entryFree>
as: <entryFree id="n3855" type="main" key="as"><orth extent="full" lang="la">as</orth>, <itype>assis</itype>, <gen>m.</gen> (<case>nom.</case> assis, Don. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0134,004:1:1:9" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ter.</author> Phorm. 1, 1, 9</bibl>, and Schol. ad <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0969,001:2:59" default="NO"><author>Pers.</author> 2, 59</bibl>; old form <orth extent="full" lang="la">assārĭus</orth>, <itype>ii</itype>, <gen>m.</gen>; and in the <sense id="n3855.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">gen. plur.</hi> assariūm, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 8:section=71" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 8, § 71</bibl> Müll.; <bibl default="NO"><author>Charis.</author> p. 58</bibl> P.) [<foreign lang="greek">ei(=s</foreign>, Dor. <foreign lang="greek">ai)/s</foreign>, Tarent. <foreign lang="greek">a)/s</foreign>, Hinter]. </sense><sense id="n3855.1" n="I" level="1"> In gen., <hi rend="ital">unity</hi>, <hi rend="ital">a unit;</hi> as a standard for different coins, weight, measure, etc. (in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:3:1, p. 61" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 3, 1, p. 61</bibl> Rode, perfectus numerus, the perfect number, fundamental number), acc. to the duodecimal system, divided into 12 parts, or uncias, with the following particular designations: uncia = 1s./12 duodecima (sc. pars) sextans = 2/12 = 1s./6 sexta quadrans = 3/12 = 1s./4 quarta, also teruncius or triuncis triens = 4/12 = 1s./3 tertia or quincunx = 5s./12 sextans cum quadrante semissis s. semis = 6/12 = 1s./2 dimidia septunx = 7s./12 quadrans cum triente bessis s. bes = 8/12 = 2/3, for beis s. binae partes assis. dodrans = 9/12 = 3s./4 terni quadrantes dextans s. decunx = 10/12 = 5s./6 quini sextantes deunx = 11s./12 undecim unciaeThe uncia was again divided into smaller parts: semuncia = 1/2 uncia = 1/24 assis. duella = 1/3 uncia = 1/36 assis. sicilicus (-um) = 1/4 uncia = 1/48 assis. sextula = 1/6 uncia = 1/72 assis. drachma = 1/8 uncia = 1/96 assis. hemisecla = 1/12 uncia = 1/144 assis. scripulum = 1/24 uncia = 1/288 assis.The multiples of the <hi rend="ital">as</hi> received the following designations: dupondius = 2 asses. tripondius s. tressis = 3 asses. (quadressis) = 4 asses. quinquessis = 5 asses. sexis (only in the connection decussissexis in <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1056,001:1" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Vitr.</author> 1</bibl>. c.) = 6 asses. septissis = 7 asses. octussis = 8 asses. nonussis (novissis?) = 9 asses. decussis = 10 asses. bicessis = 20 asses. tricessis = 30 asses, and so on to centussis = 100 asses. (Cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:L. L. 5:section=169 sq" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> L. L. 5, § 169 sq.</bibl> Müll.)</sense><sense id="n3855.2" n="II" level="1"> Esp. </sense><sense id="n3855.3" n="A. 1." level="1"> As a copper coin, the as was, acc. to the ancient custom of weighing money, originally <hi rend="ital">a pound</hi> (asses librales or aes grave), of the value of about 8 8<hi rend="ital">d.</hi>/89, or 16 2/3 cents, and was uncoined (aes rude) until Servius Tullius stamped it with the figures of animals (hence pecunia, from pecus); cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0684,001:R. R. 2:1:9" default="NO"><author>Varr.</author> R. R. 2, 1, 9</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:33:42" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 33, 3, 13, § 42</bibl> sqq. In the first Punic war, on account of the scarcity of money, the as was reduced to a sixth part of its original weight, i. e. <cb n="ASBE" /> two ounces; hence asses sextantarii (of the value of about 1 103<hi rend="ital">d.</hi>/297, or 2.8 cents), and the state gained five sixths. In the second Punic war, and the dictatorship of Fabius, the as was again reduced one half, to one ounce; hence asses unciales, about equal to 200<hi rend="ital">d.</hi>/297, or 1.4 cents. Finally, the Lex Papiria (A.U.C. 563, B.C. 191) reduced the as to half an ounce; hence asses semiunciales = 100<hi rend="ital">d.</hi>/297, or 7.9 1/3 mills, which continued as a standard even under the emperors. In all these reductions, however, the names of coins remained, independent of the weight of the as: uncia, sextans, quadrans, etc.; cf. Grotef. Gr. II. p. 253 sq.—From the small value of the as after the last reduction, the following phrases arose: quod non opus est, asse carum est, Cato ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1014,001:Ep. 94" default="NO"><author>Sen.</author> Ep. 94</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">Quod (sc. pondus auri) si comminuas, vilem redigatur ad assem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0893,004:1:1:43" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Hor.</author> S. 1, 1, 43</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">viatica ad assem Perdiderat,</quote> <trans><tr>to the last farthing</tr>,</trans> <bibl default="NO"><author>id.</author> Ep. 2, 2, 27</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ad assem impendium reddere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1318,001:1:15" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> Ep. 1, 15</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">rumores Omnes unius aestimemus assis,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:5:3" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cat.</author> 5, 3</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">Non assis facis?</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0472,001:42:13" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>id.</author> 42, 13</bibl></cit>.—Hence, </sense><sense id="n3855.4" n="2" level="3"> The proverbs, </sense><sense id="n3855.5" n="a" level="4"> Assem habeas, assem valeas, <hi rend="ital">your worth is estimated by your possessions</hi>, <bibl default="NO"><author>Petr.</author> 77, 6</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">crumena plena assium,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1254,001:20:1" default="NO"><author>Gell.</author> 20, 1</bibl></cit>.— </sense><sense id="n3855.6" n="b" level="4"> Assem elephanto dare, <hi rend="ital">to give something</hi> (as a petition, and the like) <hi rend="ital">with trembling to a superior</hi> (a metaphor derived from trained elephants, which, after playing their parts, were accustomed to take pay for themselves, which was given them with fear by the multitude; cf. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:8:14" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 8, 5, 5, § 14</bibl>), Augustus ap. <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1002,001:6:3:59" default="NO"><author>Quint.</author> 6, 3, 59</bibl>, and <bibl default="NO"><author>Macr.</author> S. 2, 4</bibl>; Varr. ap. <bibl default="NO"><author>Non.</author> p. 531, 10 sq.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n3855.7" n="B" level="2"> In inheritances and other money matters, where a division was made, the as, with its parts, was used to designate the portions. Thus haeres ex asse, <hi rend="ital">sole heir;</hi> haeres ex semisse, <hi rend="ital">he who receives one half of the inheritance;</hi> haeres ex dodrante, <hi rend="ital">he who receives three fourths;</hi> and so, haeres ex besse, triente, quadrante, sextante, etc.; <cit><quote lang="la">ex semiunciā, ex sextulā, ex duabus sextulis, etc.,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:28:5:50" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 28, 5, 50</bibl></cit>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:34:9:2" default="NO">34, 9, 2</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,1348,001:life=jul.:83" default="NO"><author>Suet.</author> Caes. 83</bibl>; <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0474,008:chapter=6" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Cic.</author> Caecin. 6</bibl> et saep.: <cit><quote lang="la">Nerva constituit, ut tu ex triente socius esses, ego ex besse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:17:2:76" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 17, 2, 76</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">bessem fundi emere ab aliquo,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:26:21:2:section=39" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 26, 21, 2, § 39</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">quadrans et semissis fundi,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:6:1:8 al" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 6, 1, 8 al.</bibl></cit>; <cit><quote lang="la">hence, in assem, in asse, or ex asse,</quote> <trans><tr>in all</tr>, <tr>entirely</tr>, <tr>completely</tr>,</trans> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:36:45" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 36, 45</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">vendere fundum in assem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:20:6:9" default="NO"><author>ib.</author> 20, 6, 9</bibl></cit>; so <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:3:3:8" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 3, 3, 8</bibl> and 9: <cit><quote lang="la">in asse,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:2:12:7" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 2, 12, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">sic in asse flunt octo menses et dies decem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:2:12:7" default="NO"><author>id.</author> 2, 12, 7</bibl></cit>: <cit><quote lang="la">ex asse aut ex parte possidere,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,2806,001:2:8:15" default="NO"><author>Dig.</author> 2, 8, 15</bibl></cit>; <bibl default="NO"><author>Sid.</author> Ep. 2, 1</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">6, 12</bibl>; <bibl default="NO">8, 6 al.</bibl>—</sense><sense id="n3855.8" n="C" level="2"> As a measure of extent. </sense><sense id="n3855.9" n="a" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">An acre</hi>, acc. to the same divisions as above, from scripulum to the as, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:5:1:9 sq" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 5, 1, 9 sq.</bibl>: <cit><quote lang="la">proscindere semissem, iterare assem,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0978,001:18:178" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Plin.</author> 18, 19, 49, § 178</bibl></cit>.—</sense><sense id="n3855.10" n="b" level="4"> <hi rend="ital">A foot</hi>, <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0845,001:5:3" default="NO"><author>Col.</author> 5, 3</bibl>.—</sense><sense id="n3855.11" n="D" level="2"> Of weight, <hi rend="ital">a pound</hi>, acc. to the same division; cf. <cit><quote lang="la">Fann. Pond. 41: In haec solide sexta face assis eat,</quote> <bibl n="Perseus:abo:phi,0959,003:60" default="NO" valid="yes"><author>Ov.</author> Med. Fac. 60</bibl></cit>.← Mathematicians (v. Vitr. l. c.) called the number 6 perfectus numerus (since 1 + 2 + 3 = 6), and formed, accordingly, the following terminology: 1 = sextans, as a dice-number . unio. 2 = triens . . . . . . . . . . binio. 3 = semissis . . . . . . . . . . ternio. 4 = bessis (<foreign lang="greek">dimoiros</foreign>) . . . . . quaternio. 5 = quintarius . . . . . . . quinio. 6 = perfectus numerus . . . . senio. 7 = <foreign lang="greek">e)/fektos</foreign>, sex adjecto asse = 6 + 1. 8 = adtertiarius, sex adjectā tertiā = 6 + 2 (<foreign lang="greek">e)pi/tritos</foreign>). 9 = sesquialter, sex adjectā dimidiā = 6 + 3 (<foreign lang="greek">h(mio/lios</foreign>). 10 = bes alter, sex duabus partibus additis = 6 + 4 (<foreign lang="greek">e)pidi/moiros</foreign>). 11 = adquintarius, sex quinque partibus additis = 6 + 5 (<foreign lang="greek">e)pipenta/moiros</foreign>). 12 = duplio (<foreign lang="greek">diplasi/wn</foreign>).</sense></entryFree>
asa: <entryFree id="n3856" type="main" key="a_sa"><orth extent="full" lang="la">āsa</orth>, v. ara <sense id="n3856.0" n="I" level="1"><hi rend="ital">init.</hi></sense></entryFree>
